10128{_}884{_}Such was the warfare in the mountains of the Province of Tittery, and Abd-el-Kader by his swift movements kept the enemy ever on the alert, and often in trouble, from the frontiers of Morocco to those of Tunis.
10128{_}885{_}The real and decisive struggle began early in 1841.
10128{_}886{_}The right man was at last found by the French to deal with the hitherto indomitable Sultan of Tittery and Oran.
10128{_}887{_}The Government at Paris had begun in some sort to understand the power of their formidable adversary, and a serious effort was to be made.
10128{_}888{_}On February 22, 1841, General Bugeaud assumed office as Governor-General of Algeria.
10128{_}889{_}He had now come, not in the mood and with the policy of the day when he concluded the Treaty of the Tafna, but as one whose task it was to crush every rival power in Algeria.
10128{_}890{_}For this end, eighty-five thousand men were placed under his command.
10128{_}891{_}Thomas Bugeaud was a man of great ability, and he has the credit of devising the only method by which such an antagonist as Abd-el-Kader, in such a country, could be subdued.
10128{_}892{_}Against an adversary so mobile, so full of expedients and resource, mobility and incessantly offensive movements offered the only chance of success.
10128{_}893{_}The French Commander knew that it was no mere army, but a people in arms, that he was to encounter.
10128{_}894{_}His forces were at once organized in many small, compact columns, each composed of a few infantry battalions and two squadrons of horse, with a little transport train of mules and camels and two mountain howitzers.
10128{_}895{_}Picked men alone, acclimatized and used to toil, were employed, and they carried nothing but their muskets and ammunition, with a little food.
10128{_}896{_}These columns were placed under the command of such energetic leaders as Changarnier and Cavaignac, Canrobert and Pelissier, Bedeau and Lamoriciere, St. Arnaud and the Duc d'Aumale.
10128{_}897{_}The campaign opened with the revictualling of Medea and Miliana, with great losses to the French, as Abd-el-Kader disputed every inch of the ground.
10128{_}898{_}Bugeaud, personally operating in Oran, reached Tekedemt on May 25th, and found it deserted and in flames.
10128{_}899{_}Boghar, Saida, and other fortresses were successively destroyed.
10128{_}900{_}The enemies of the Sultan were paying a heavy price for success.
10128{_}901{_}At the end of 1841 Bugeaud, out of sixty thousand men in the field, had only four thousand fit for duty.
10128{_}902{_}The rest had perished or were invalided for the time, from the toil of marches, incessant fighting, and the heat of the climate.
10128{_}903{_}The French Government's proposals of peace, on certain terms, only confirmed Abd-el-Kader in his resolve to try the extremities of war.
10128{_}904{_}Bugeaud's main object was to establish permanent centres of action in the very heart of the Arab confederation of tribes, and, by rapidly consecutive expeditions radiating from these centres, to give his troops the ubiquity of Abd-el-Kader's forces.
10128{_}905{_}The chief seat of the Sultan's power was the Province of Oran, and this was made the principal scene of operations.
10128{_}906{_}Mascara was held by Lamoriciere, Tlemsen by Bedeau.
10128{_}907{_}Changarnier was in observation on the western frontier of the plain of Algiers; Tittery was menaced by D'Aumale.
10128{_}908{_}From Oran and Mostaganem three columns were sent forth against the tribes occupying the large expanse of territory lying between the Atlas Mountains and the Mediterranean, and the tribes extending toward the Sahara.
10128{_}909{_}The first force, headed by Bugeaud in person, marched along the valley of the Cheliff, and then joined the second column under Changarnier, coming from Blida.
10128{_}910{_}The third body, under Lamoriciere, aimed at pushing Abd-el-Kader back to the south in order to separate him from the tribes assailed by Changarnier and Bugeaud.
10128{_}911{_}The plan of campaign was formidable for the Arabs, but it was encountered by the Sultan with wonderful skill and daring in a struggle which involved some thrilling episodes, Lamoriciere, in his efforts to overtake the foe, was constantly baffled.
10128{_}912{_}Hearing that Abd-el-Kader was before Mascara, he hurried thither by forced marches, only to find that his enemy had passed by his rear and was raiding a tribe friendly to the French.
10128{_}913{_}Pursuing in the new direction, the French leader was outmaneuvre by the Sultan's bold and rapid dash across the Cheliff, placing his Arabs between Bugeaud and the sea, and recovering his ascendency over the tribes in that region.
10128{_}914{_}Abd-el-Kader then swept in a _razzia_ to the south of Miliana, and soon appeared in full force in the Sahara as the bewildered French pursuers returned to their cantonments in despair of reaching him.
10128{_}915{_}This is a sample of the evolutions by which genius made amends for inferiority of force.
10128{_}916{_}The ablest military combinations were rendered abortive by an enemy that was ever slipping between columns, flitting in the front, hovering on the flanks, assailing the rear, and, with perfect knowledge of the country, was sometimes in the mountains and again in the plains, ubiquitous, unattainable for serious conflict.
10128{_}917{_}Abd-el-Kader, leaving his caliphs to maintain this exasperating species of warfare in the Province of Oran, made for the frontiers of Morocco.
10128{_}918{_}There many tribes had submitted under the influence of Bedeau's military and diplomatic skill.
10128{_}919{_}The Sultan's communications with the country whence he drew his weapons, clothing, and ammunition were seriously threatened.
10128{_}920{_}His appearance at once brought back the Kabyles of Nedrouma to their allegiance, and their example was followed by other tribes, with the result that his army was increased to the number of three thousand cavalry and five thousand infantry.
10128{_}921{_}Able now to confront the enemy, Abd-el-Kader during the months of March and April, 1842, had frequent encounters with Bedeau, The issue was yet indecisive when the Sultan was called away to Mascara to deal with Lamoriciere, who had been gaining ground and winning over tribes, including even a large part of Abd-el-Kader's own people, the Hashems.
10128{_}922{_}Lamoriciere, believing the Sultan to be still engaged with Bedeau, had marched toward the Sahara, and Abd-el-Kader, by a mingling of severe punishment and mild treatment, regained most of his old authority.
10128{_}923{_}Lamoriciere, on receiving the news of his presence, hastened back to find his recent work undone and to be assailed by the tribes who had so lately joined him.
10128{_}924{_}Fighting his way bravely on to an encounter with the great leader of the Arabs, the French general heard of him as in force at Tekedemt.
10128{_}925{_}When he reached that place he found that Abd-el-Kader had fallen on Changarnier toward Miliana.
10128{_}926{_}That general, knowing nothing of the Sultan's approach, found himself enveloped by a vast force of Arabs and Kabyles, regulars and irregulars, horse and foot, led on by Abd-el-Kader in person and charging furiously on all sides.
10128{_}927{_}After two days and nights of incessant battle, in which men closed fiercely with pistols, swords, bayonets, and yataghans, the Sultan vanished with his force, leaving the French too exhausted and crippled by their losses for pursuit.
10128{_}928{_}Two days later tidings reached them that he was in the Metidja, ravaging the plain and carrying terror to the very gates of Algiers.
10128{_}929{_}Abd-el-Kader then bore away to the Atlas, ascended the mountains, penetrated beyond Tittery and reached the Sahara, everywhere inspiriting the tribes and raising fresh forces.
10128{_}930{_}After sweeping over three hundred leagues of ground he returned, in recruited strength and new energy, to press upon Lamoriciere and his garrison at Mascara with all the rigors of a winter blockade.
10128{_}931{_}In spite of his wonderful efforts, the Sultan could not but feel that he was struggling with adverse fortune.
10128{_}932{_}The enemy by the seizure of his fixed establishments had gained possession of a large part of his territory and of the strongholds that had contained his stores of war.
10128{_}933{_}His regular army had almost disappeared, and much of his credit among the Arabs had departed.
10128{_}934{_}The _ketna_, which was his ancestral abode, had been laid waste.
10128{_}935{_}He could not protect the families of his most faithful adherents from constant exposure, in spite of his vigilant activity, to the outrages of the detested infidels.
10128{_}936{_}In this position, he resolved to remove from the scene of warfare those whom it was impossible for him to desert with any regard to feelings of religion and humanity.
10128{_}937{_}He formed his famous _smala_, a new and remarkable organization consisting of a gathering of private families.
10128{_}938{_}To this moving asylum of refuge and safety the Arab tribes sent their treasure, their herds, their women and children, their sick and aged persons.
10128{_}939{_}The smala was a great travelling capital, containing at first more than twenty thousand souls, following the Sultan's movements; sometimes in advance to the more cultivated regions, or in retreat to the Sahara, according to the fluctuations of the contest which he was so bravely waging.
10128{_}940{_}In the Sahara, the tents of the smala spread to the distant horizon.
10128{_}941{_}In the Tell, they filled the valley and rose up the slopes of the hills.
10128{_}942{_}All the arrangements were of military regularity.
10128{_}943{_}The different _deiras_, or households, with tents varying in number with their dwellers, were distributed into four great encampments.
10128{_}944{_}Each deira knew its appointed place.
10128{_}945{_}Each chief had his station marked and his special duties assigned.
10128{_}946{_}Four tribes were set apart to protect and guide the smala in its wanderings, and the guard was composed of regular troops.
10128{_}947{_}The existence of this organization, ever growing in extent, became a powerful check on the disaffection of the tribes.
10128{_}948{_}When the French leaders tempted them with fair promises, the warriors bethought them of the pledges: the women, the children, the flocks and herds, which were in the Sultan's hands.
10128{_}949{_}The genius of Abd-el-Kader had created a new and widely extended political engine.
10128{_}950{_}When the French leaders had learned to appreciate the importance of the smala its capture or dispersal became a chief object with all officers from the generals of corps to the colonels in charge of detachments.
10128{_}951{_}The campaign of 1843 was opened by Lamoriciere, who occupied Tekedemt.
10128{_}952{_}Abd-el-Kader with about fifteen hundred horsemen watched his movements from some neighboring woods.
10128{_}953{_}He knew that the French commander's object was the smala, and he remained in ambush for twenty days.
10128{_}954{_}He and his men lived on acorns; the horses were fed on leaves.
10128{_}955{_}One day a stray sheep was found.
10128{_}956{_}The Sultan would have none of it, and said, "Take it to my starving soldiers," as he turned to his meal of acorns.
10128{_}957{_}Twice was Lamoriciere repulsed in his search, and then a traitor revealed the exact place of the smala encampment.
10128{_}958{_}Lamoriciere remained to occupy the attention of Abd-el-Kader, and the French column stationed at Medea was selected for the attack.
10128{_}959{_}The leadership was intrusted to the Duc d'Aumale, and on May 10, 1843, he started from Boghar with thirteen hundred infantry, six hundred horse, and two field-guns.
10128{_}960{_}The indicated place of encampment was found empty, and the French column wandered about in uncertain fashion.
10128{_}961{_}At break of day on May 16th the traitor made known the new spot of the smala's halt, and D'Aumale at once daringly advanced with his cavalry alone.
10128{_}962{_}The surprise created a panic among the people.
10128{_}963{_}The guard of five hundred regulars fired a volley and fled.
10128{_}964{_}A handful of the Hashem tribe bravely strove to stem the torrent, but they were swept away in the rout, and in an hour all was over.
10128{_}965{_}The smala was broken up amid scenes of terrible confusion and despair, including the extraordinary sight of a promiscuous mass of camels, dromedaries, horses, mules, oxen, and sheep careering and plunging on the plain.
10128{_}966{_}There was little bloodshed, but the French victors were in possession of hostages of the utmost value in the families of Abd-el-Ka-der's most influential chiefs.
10128{_}967{_}His own family had escaped.
10128{_}968{_}The booty taken was immense, comprising thousands of animals; the Sultan's valuable library of rare Arabic manuscripts; the military chest containing some millions of francs, and the chests of his caliphs and other high officers, filled with gold and silver coins and costly jewellery.
10128{_}969{_}The French soldiers baled out dollars and doubloons in their shakos, and helped themselves to diamonds and pearls.
10128{_}970{_}This dreadful blow, when the news reached him in the woods where he watched near Lamoriciere's command, almost overwhelmed, for a time, even the exalted and undaunted spirit of the Sultan.
10128{_}971{_}He spent some hours alone in his tent, in meditation and prayer.
10128{_}972{_}He came forth with a smile and addressed his chiefs, his officers, and men as they stood outside in groups, some downcast and silent, some bitterly cursing their foe and fate.
10128{_}973{_}He reminded them that the dear objects now lost had impeded the movements of the holy war against the infidels, and that those who had fallen were now in paradise.
10128{_}974{_}The next day he wrote to his caliphs, bidding them not to be discouraged; they would thenceforth be lighter and in better order for war.
10128{_}975{_}In fact at the time of the Duc d'Aumale's attack, the population of the smala amounted to not less than sixty thousand.
10128{_}976{_}Not more than three thousand prisoners were taken; the rest of the Arabs were dispersed in all directions.
10128{_}977{_}Some fell among Arab tribes who plundered them; others were overtaken by Lamoriciere.
10128{_}978{_}The blow was, on the whole, irreparable in its effects upon the influence of the Sultan.
10128{_}979{_}Every day brought tidings of the defection of some great tribe.
10128{_}980{_}The ranks of his enemies were swelled by large contingents of Arabs.
10128{_}981{_}Worse things were in store for the brave man contending with ill-fortune.
10128{_}982{_}His ablest caliphs were removed by captivity or death in action; the distant provinces fell a prey to the foe.
10128{_}983{_}The Province of Oran became the scene of a desperate struggle.
10128{_}984{_}With a chosen and devoted band of five thousand men Abd-el-Kader made his presence felt at all points.
10128{_}985{_}Now he fell on recreant tribes; now he made head against the French columns.
10128{_}986{_}Ever in the van, leading on the charge, plunging into the thickest of the fight, by his example he encouraged and inspired his followers.
10128{_}987{_}His bravest warriors fell around him; his horses were slain under him; his burnoose was torn with bullets; but still he fought on.
10128{_}988{_}The world's record can show no more brilliant instance of almost superhuman heroism.
10128{_}989{_}Once he was taken unawares.
10128{_}990{_}On September 23, 1843, he was encamped near Sidi Yusuf with a battalion of infantry and five hundred irregular horse.
10128{_}991{_}A spy made known his position to Lamoriciere, who was at a distance of six leagues.
10128{_}992{_}The French General at once led out in person the Second Chasseurs d'Afrique.
10128{_}993{_}A night's march covered the intervening space and the spot was reached in the gray of dawn.
10128{_}994{_}The Sultan was aroused from sleep by cries of "The French!
10128{_}995{_}the French!"
10128{_}996{_}He had barely time to mount.
10128{_}997{_}He might have escaped, but he preferred the risk of death to the double stain of surprise and flight.
10128{_}998{_}His infantry seized their arms and fired a volley; his cavalry rallied at his voice.
10128{_}999{_}Then as the smoke slowly rolled away he dashed into the French chasseurs, dispersed them by the sudden shock, and after a few minutes' hard fighting drew off his whole force in perfect order.
10128{_}1000{_}The Beni-Amers, the men whose four thousand sabres had waved in exultation around the young leader of the Djehad; the men whose splendid courage had opened before him the path of glory and of empire, had gone over to the French.
10128{_}1001{_}Abd-el-Kader resolved to attack them.
10128{_}1002{_}Suddenly descending upon them he swept through their encampments, slew numbers, and carried off a great booty.
10128{_}1003{_}A French battalion stationed among them vainly strove to arrest his progress.
10128{_}1004{_}An Arab chief, one of his old followers, boldly singled him out, rode up, and fired at him point-blank.
10128{_}1005{_}The ball missed, and Abd-el-Kader shot the traitor dead with his pistol.
10128{_}1006{_}The Sultan knew that all was lost unless he could obtain external aid.
10128{_}1007{_}The smala was now reduced to his own deira, a bare thousand souls, wandering about in miserable fashion.
10128{_}1008{_}After another desperate engagement with Lamoriciere during which the Arab women cheered on the warriors, and Abd-el-Kader and his men fighting in the presence of their wives and children performed new prodigies of valor, he succeeded in safely establishing the noncombatants on the territory of Morocco.
10128{_}1009{_}Bugeaud, now become a marshal, wrote to his Government declaring that all serious warfare was finished.
10128{_}1010{_}In the summer of 1844, the violation of Abderrahman's territory by French troops under Lamoriciere and Bedeau led to some warfare, in which the Moroccan troops were twice defeated.
10128{_}1011{_}The people of the country were strongly in favor of Abd-el-Kader; and when their Sultan, after a French bombardment of Tangiers and Mogador, made a treaty with France by which the Algerian hero was "placed beyond the pale of the law throughout the Empire of Morocco, as well as in Algeria," and was to be "pursued by main force by the Moroccans on their own territory," the Moorish population was filled with resentment.
10128{_}1012{_}Letters reached Abd-el-Kader from Fez, the capital, dictated and signed by the first grandees in the State, both civil and military, and from the commercial classes, inviting him to ascend the throne of his ancestors.
10128{_}1013{_}Had he been a mere adventurer or usurper he might have lived henceforth, and died, Emperor of Morocco, But his whole soul was patriotically bent on one object, the freedom and independence of Algeria.
10128{_}1014{_}He disdained to wear a borrowed crown.
10128{_}1015{_}As he afterward declared, "His religion forbade him to injure a sovereign chosen and appointed by God."
10128{_}1016{_}During the year 1844 the Sultan had made a rapid incursion into the Tell, everywhere appealing to the tribes; but he found the national spirit overawed by the presence of French detachments in all directions, and he returned to his deira in despondent spirit.
10128{_}1017{_}He now received appeals from some of his devoted caliphs to undertake a fresh campaign, especially from the loyal and chivalrous Ben Salem, who dwelt in the gorges of the Djur jura Mountains.
10128{_}1018{_}To him Abd-el-Kader replied, promising to come "as soon as affairs in the west were settled."
10128{_}1019{_}Months passed away and the Arab tribes who had submitted began to feel the pressure of French domination and to resent the supercilious conduct of French officials.
10128{_}1020{_}In the spring of 1845 their former Sultan reappeared.
10128{_}1021{_}He swept down into the valley of the Tafna and routed and cut to pieces a French detachment.
10128{_}1022{_}In this action the lower part of his right ear was carried away by a musket-ball, the only wound which he ever received.
10128{_}1023{_}Another detachment of six hundred men laid down their arms without firing a shot.
10128{_}1024{_}Some stir was made among the Arabs by these successes, and the French commanders took alarm.
10128{_}1025{_}Lamoriciere, Cavaignac, and Bedeau wrote pressing letters for reinforcements, and urged the return of Bugeaud.
10128{_}1026{_}The most formidable foe of Abd-el-Kader reached the scene of action in October, 1845, bringing fresh forces, and in a week he took the field at the head of a hundred twenty thousand men.
10128{_}1027{_}This fact is the highest eulogy that can be accorded to the military prowess of a man who so long defied the power of France.
10128{_}1028{_}The end of the great career was rapidly coming.
10128{_}1029{_}After another vain appeal to the Moorish ruler even Abd-el-Kader felt that all was lost.
10128{_}1030{_}A French writer in the _Biographie generale_ truly declares:  "The greatness of the man was strikingly displayed in the very hour of his downfall.
10128{_}1031{_}Destitute of resources, surrounded by foes, at open enmity with the Emperor of Morocco, wandering like a hunted lion, with hardly any comrade but his horse, no shelter except his tent, Abd-el-Kader still inspired a terror which forced his enemies to keep a great army on foot in Algeria for protection against possible attacks at his hand."
10128{_}1032{_}In his deira, at this time, all was despondency and grief.
10128{_}1033{_}His own brothers had abandoned him.
10128{_}1034{_}Ben Salem, the faithful, long-tried, devoted friend and follower, was a voluntary prisoner in the French camp.
10128{_}1035{_}Abd-el-Kader's whole force was fewer than two thousand men, but among these were twelve hundred horsemen, the flower of the Algerian cavalry.
10128{_}1036{_}Most of them had been his inseparable comrades, partakers in all his hardships and dangers, throughout his career.
10128{_}1037{_}During a short period of rest he summoned them daily around him and aroused new enthusiasm among the bronzed veterans by his eloquent words.
10128{_}1038{_}On December 9, 1847, the deira was stationed on Moorish territory, at Agueddin, on the left bank of the Melouia.
10128{_}1039{_}It comprised in all about five thousand souls.
10128{_}1040{_}The next day news arrived that a great Moorish host under the Sultan's two sons was only three hours' march away.
10128{_}1041{_}On January 11th, Abd-el-Kader gathered his armed force, marched at dead of night and fell furiously on the first division of the Moors and Arabs.
10128{_}1042{_}The slumbering foe awoke to see the thick darkness illumined by flashes of light from muskets.
10128{_}1043{_}Seized with panic, the men rushed away in all directions, abandoning arms, tents, and baggage.
10128{_}1044{_}In the mean time Abd-el-Kader and his men swept onward and attacked the second division, which was also defeated and dispersed.
10128{_}1045{_}In half an hour the third division was reached.
10128{_}1046{_}This force had time to prepare for defence, and the assailants withdrew before a steady fire of infantry and artillery to an adjacent hill.
10128{_}1047{_}At midday five thousand Moorish cavalry moved out against Abd-el-Kader's little army.
10128{_}1048{_}At charging distance he led on his men, swept through the foe, and by a skilful combination of assault and retreat regained his deira by the river Melouia, before sunset.
10128{_}1049{_}The deira had nearly effected its passage across the river, with the baggage and the spoils taken from the enemy, when the Moorish army was seen cautiously advancing.
10128{_}1050{_}The situation was full of peril.
10128{_}1051{_}The deira had never been so exposed.
10128{_}1052{_}The ammunition was expended and the infantry was thus counted out of the fight.
10128{_}1053{_}Abd-el-Kader could only depend on his "Old Guard"--his matchless cavalry.
10128{_}1054{_}At length the Melouia was passed, and, although the foe was pressing on, he would not leave its bank until the noncombatants had gained a full hour in advance.
10128{_}1055{_}Then the deira crossed another stream and reached a place of safety, for the time, on French territory.
10128{_}1056{_}Not a life had been lost nor a beast of burden of all that crowd of men, women, children, and animals.
10128{_}1057{_}Coolness, intrepidity, and skill had been their protectors.
10128{_}1058{_}Of the fighting men, however, more than two hundred had been slain, and nearly all the rest were suffering from wounds.
10128{_}1059{_}Abd-el-Kader now turned toward the hills inhabited by a tribe which still, in part, adhered to him.
10128{_}1060{_}His horsemen followed him in anxious silence, suffering and exhausted.
10128{_}1061{_}The rain fell in torrents.
10128{_}1062{_}Their chief was tormented by conflicting thoughts.
10128{_}1063{_}A French camp was visible in the distance, three hours' march away, occupying a pass.
10128{_}1064{_}He and his cavalry might yet escape by narrow defiles into the Sahara.
10128{_}1065{_}But what of his aged mother, his wife and children, his helpless followers in the deira?
10128{_}1066{_}All would become captives to the foe.
10128{_}1067{_}He called his men around him and reminded them of the oath which, eight years before on the renewal of the war, they had taken at Medea that they would never forsake him in any danger or suffering.
10128{_}1068{_}All declared themselves ready still to adhere to it.
10128{_}1069{_}He set before them the peril of the people in the deira and suggested submission.
10128{_}1070{_}All the warriors cried: "Perish women and children so long as you are safe and able to renew the battles of God.
10128{_}1071{_}You are our head, our Sultan; fight or surrender, as you will, we will follow you wherever you choose to lead."
10128{_}1072{_}After a few moments' pause Abd-el-Kader declared that the struggle was over.
10128{_}1073{_}The tribes were tired of the war and there was nothing left but submission.
10128{_}1074{_}He would ask the French for a safe-conduct for himself and his family, and for all who chose to follow him, to another Mussulman country.
10128{_}1075{_}The universal answer was, "Sultan, let your will be done!"
10128{_}1076{_}The incessant rain rendered it impossible to write down any terms.
10128{_}1077{_}Abd-el-Kader therefore affixed his seal to a piece of paper, and despatched it in charge of two horsemen to the French general as a sign of authorization on his part for demands to be verbally made.
10128{_}1078{_}It was Lamoriciere who received the two emissaries; and he sent a verbal reply, acceding to all proposals.
10128{_}1079{_}Abd-el-Kader then sent a letter, and received in reply a written promise and stipulation that the Sultan and his family should be conducted to St. Jean d'Acre or Alexandria.
10128{_}1080{_}The new Governor-General, the Duc d'Aumale, was close at hand, and on the evening of December 23, 1847, the fallen hero, attended by some of his chiefs and men, escorted by five hundred French cavalry, who showed great respect and sympathy for the captives, arrived at headquarters.
10128{_}1081{_}Abd-el-Kader, attended by Lamoriciere and Cavaignac, was presented to the son of Louis Philippe.
10128{_}1082{_}The Prince pledged himself that Lamoriciere's promise and stipulation should be strictly observed.
10128{_}1083{_}He knew little that his father's throne was about to fall, and that the decision as to Abd-el-Kader's fate would, within a few weeks, rest in far different hands.
10128{_}1084{_}The ex-Sultan then withdrew to his deira, which had now joined the French encampment.
10128{_}1085{_}On the next morning, December 24th, the Governor-General held a review.
10128{_}1086{_}His honored prisoner and guest, riding a splendid black charger of the purest Arab breed, and surrounded by his chiefs, awaited his return from the field.
10128{_}1087{_}When the Prince approached, Abd-el-Kader dismounted and offered his steed as a present in testimony of his gratitude, and expressed the hope that he might always bear his new master in safety and happiness.
10128{_}1088{_}The Duc d'Aumale replied, "I accept it as a homage rendered to France, the protection of which country will henceforth be ever extended toward you, and as a sign that the past is forgotten."
10128{_}1089{_}On December 25th the Algerian hero embarked with his family and followers in a French frigate for Toulon.
10128{_}1090{_}He had seen the last of his native land.
10128{_}1091{_}Lamoriciere accompanied him on board and supplemented his poor resources with a present of four thousand francs, receiving Abd-el-Kader's sword in return.
10128{_}1092{_}The _Moniteur_ of January 3, 1848, paid a high tribute to the genius and ascendency of the captive in these words: "The subjugation of Abd-el-Kader is an event of immense importance to France.
10128{_}1093{_}It assures the tranquillity of our conquest.
10128{_}1094{_}To-day France can, if necessary, transport to other quarters the hundred thousand men who hold the conquered populations under her yoke."
10128{_}1095{_}(1847) THE MEXICAN WAR, John Bonner   When President Polk began his Administration, the United States Government had become involved in two boundary disputes--one relating to Oregon, the other to Texas and Mexico.
10128{_}1096{_}Out of the latter came the Mexican War, concerning the political causes and merits of which there were then and ever since have been wide differences of opinion among the American people.
10128{_}1097{_}Polk's election by the Democrats in 1844 had turned mainly upon the question of annexing Texas.
10128{_}1098{_}Just before he came into office the annexation was made.
10128{_}1099{_}Texas claimed as her western boundary the Rio Grande.
10128{_}1100{_}Mexico held that the western limit was the Nueces.
10128{_}1101{_}Between the two rivers there was a large area of disputed territory.
10128{_}1102{_}The Texan claim was opposed by many American statesmen and publicists, and by some was denounced--as the annexation of Texas had been--as an aggressive move against Mexico.
10128{_}1103{_}But the United States Government supported the cause of Texas.
10128{_}1104{_}General Zachary Taylor, who had served in the War of 1812, and afterward in several Indian wars, took command of the army in Texas in 1845.
10128{_}1105{_}In January, 1846, he was ordered to occupy positions on or near the left bank of the Rio Grande del Norte.
10128{_}1106{_}This order and its execution have been held by some writers to constitute an act of war, but war was not formally declared by the United States till May 11th.
10128{_}1107{_}Taylor, with a small force, had several slight encounters with Mexican troops, after which he won the battle of Palo Alto (May 8, 1846), near the southern extremity of Texas; and that of Resaca de la Palma (May 9th), also in Texas, four miles north of Matamoros, Mexico.
10128{_}1108{_}He took possession of Matamoros May 18th.
10128{_}1109{_}With six thousand men, against about ten thousand Mexicans under Ampudia, Taylor captured Monterey, Mexico (September 24th), and at Buena Vista, February 22-23, 1847, with five thousand troops, he defeated fifteen thousand Mexicans under Santa Anna, then President of Mexico and commander of her army.
10128{_}1110{_}The war was now transferred to the district between Vera Cruz and the City of Mexico, the capital, and was henceforth conducted for the United States by General Winfield Scott, whose previous military career had been much the same as General Taylor's.
10128{_}1111{_}Scott had been made Major-General and Commander-in-Chief of the Army in 1841.
10128{_}1112{_}His first operation in Mexico was the taking of Vera Cruz, the principal Mexican seaport, on the Gulf of Mexico.
10128{_}1113{_}With the aid of a fleet he besieged the city in March, 1847, and on the 27th received its surrender.
10128{_}1114{_}At Cerro Gordo (April 17th and 18th) he won an important victory that opened his way through the mountains toward his objective, the city of Mexico.
10128{_}1115{_}Reenforcements gradually reached him, and by the first of August he was ready to move on the valley of Mexico with about eleven thousand men.
10128{_}1116{_}From this stage to the fall of the capital, completing the conquest of the country, Bonner's account gives a graphic recital of events.
10128{_}1117{_}The city was held by Americans from September 14, 1847, the day they entered it, until the signing of the Treaty of Guadalupe-Hidalgo (February 2, 1848), which ended the war.
10128{_}1118{_}With the energy that characterized Santa Anna throughout the Mexican War, he had prepared for a desperate defence.
10128{_}1119{_}Civil strife had been silenced, funds raised, an army of twenty-five thousand men mustered, and every precaution taken which genius could suggest or science indicate.
10128{_}1120{_}Nature had done much for him.
10128{_}1121{_}Directly in front of the invading army lay the large lakes of Xochimilco and Chalco.
10128{_}1122{_}These turned, vast marshes, intersected by ditches and for the most part impassable, surrounded the city on the east and the south--on which side Scott was advancing--for several miles.
10128{_}1123{_}The only approaches were by causeways; and these Santa Anna had taken prodigious pains to guard.
10128{_}1124{_}The national road to Vera Cruz--which Scott must have taken had he marched on the north side of the lakes--was commanded by a fort mounting fifty-one guns on an impregnable hill called El Penon.
10128{_}1125{_}Should he turn the southern side of the lakes, a field of lava, deemed almost impassable for troops, interposed a primary obstacle; and fortified positions at San Antonio, San Angel, and Churubusco, with an intrenched camp at Contreras, were likewise to be surmounted before the southern causeways could be reached.
10128{_}1126{_}Beyond these there yet remained the formidable castle of Chapultepec and the strong enclosure of Molino del Rey, to be stormed before the city gates could be reached.
10128{_}1127{_}Powerful batteries had been mounted at all these points, and ample garrisons detailed to serve them.
10128{_}1128{_}The bone and muscle of Mexico were there.
10128{_}1129{_}Goaded by defeat, Santa Anna never showed so much vigor; ambition fired Valencia; patriotism stirred the soul of Alvarez; Canalizo, maddened by the odium into which he had fallen, was boiling to regain his soubriquet of the "Lion of Mexico."
10128{_}1130{_}With a constancy equal to anything recorded of the Roman Senate, the Mexican Congress, on learning of the defeat at Cerro Gordo, had voted unanimously that anyone opening negotiations with the enemy should be deemed a traitor; and the citizens with one accord had ratified the vote.
10128{_}1131{_}Within six months Mexico had lost two splendid armies in two pitched battles against the troops now advancing against the capital; but she never lost heart, and her spirit quailed not.
10128{_}1132{_}The engineers reporting that the fortress on El Penon could not be carried without a loss of one-third the army, Scott decided to move by the south of the lakes; and Worth accordingly advanced, leading the van, as far as San Augustin, nine miles from the city of Mexico.
10128{_}1133{_}There a large field of lava, known as the Pedregal, barred the way.
10128{_}1134{_}On the one side, two miles from San Augustin, the fortified works at San Antonio commanded the passage between the field and the lake; on the other, the ground was so much broken that infantry alone could advance, and General Valencia occupied an intrenched camp, with a heavy battery, near the village of Contreras, three miles distant.
10128{_}1135{_}Scott determined to attack on both sides, and sent forward General William J.
10128{_}1136{_}Worth on the east, and General Gideon J. Pillow and General David E. Twiggs on the west.
10128{_}1137{_}The latter advanced as fast as possible over the masses of lava on the morning of the 19th, and by 2 P.M. a couple of light batteries were placed in position and opened fire on the Mexican camp.
10128{_}1138{_}At the same time General Persifor Smith conceived the plan of turning Valencia's left, and hastened along the path through the Pedregal in the direction of a village called San Jeronimo.
10128{_}1139{_}Colonel Riley followed.
10128{_}1140{_}Pillow sent Cadwallader's brigade on the same line, and later in the day Morgan's regiment was likewise despatched toward that point.
10128{_}1141{_}They drove in the Mexican pickets and skirmishers, dispersed a few parties of lancers, and occupied the village without loss.
10128{_}1142{_}Seeing the movement, Santa Anna hastened to Valencia's support with twelve thousand men.
10128{_}1143{_}He was discovered by Cadwallader just as the latter gained the village road; and appreciating the vast importance of preventing a junction between the two Mexican generals, that gallant officer did not hesitate to draw up his brigade in order of battle.
10128{_}1144{_}So broken was the ground that Santa Anna could not see the amount of force opposed to him, and declined the combat.
10128{_}1145{_}This was all Cadwallader wanted.
10128{_}1146{_}Shields's brigade was advancing through the Pedregal, and the troops which had already crossed were rapidly moving to the rear of Valencia's camp.
10128{_}1147{_}Night too was close at hand.
10128{_}1148{_}When it fell, Smith's, Riley's, and Cadwallader's commands had gained the point they sought.
10128{_}1149{_}Shields joined them at ten o'clock; and at midnight Captain Lee crossed the Pedregal, with a message from General Smith to General Scott, to say that he would begin the attack at daybreak next morning.
10128{_}1150{_}It rained all night and the men lay in the mud without fires.
10128{_}1151{_}At three in the morning (August 20th) the word was passed to march.
10128{_}1152{_}Such pitchy darkness covered the face of the plain that Smith ordered every man to touch his front file as he marched.
10128{_}1153{_}Now and then a flash of lightning lighted the narrow ravine; occasionally a straggling moonbeam pierced the clouds and shed an uncertain glimmer on the heights; but these flitting guides served only to make the darkness seem darker.
10128{_}1154{_}The soldiers groped their way, stumbling over stones and brushwood, and did not gain the rear of the camp till day broke.
10128{_}1155{_}Then Riley bade his men look to the priming of their guns, and reload those which the rain had wet.
10128{_}1156{_}With the first ray of daylight the firing had begun again between the Mexican camp and Ransom's corps stationed in front and Shields's brigade at San Jeronimo.
10128{_}1157{_}Almost at the same moment Riley began to ascend the height in the rear.
10128{_}1158{_}Before he reached the crest, his engineers, who had gone forward to reconnoitre, came running back to say that his advance had been detected, that two guns were being pointed against him, and a body of infantry were sallying from the camp, The news braced the men's nerves.
10128{_}1159{_}They gained the ridge, and stood a tremendous volley from the Mexicans without flinching.
10128{_}1160{_}Hanson of the Seventh--a gallant officer and an excellent man--was shot down with many others; but the Mexicans had done their worst.
10128{_}1161{_}With steady aim the volley was returned; and ere the smoke rose a cheer rang through the ravine, and Riley fell with a swoop on the intrenchments.
10128{_}1162{_}With bayonet and butt of musket, the Second and Seventh drove the enemy from his guns, leaping into his camp and slaughtering all before them.
10128{_}1163{_}Up rushed Smith's own brigade on the left, driving a party of Mexicans before them, and charging with the bayonet straight at Torrejon's cavalry, which was drawn up in order of battle.
10128{_}1164{_}Defeat was marked on their faces.
10128{_}1165{_}Valencia was nowhere to be found.
10128{_}1166{_}Salas strove vainly to rouse his men to defend themselves with energy; Torrejon's horse, smitten with panic, broke and fled at the advance of our infantry.
10128{_}1167{_}Riley hurled the Mexicans from their camp after a struggle of a quarter of an hour; and as they rushed down the ravine, their own cavalry rode over them, trampling down more men than the bayonet and ball had laid low.
10128{_}1168{_}On the right, as they fled, Cadwallader's brigade poured in a destructive volley; and Shields, throwing his party across the road, obstructed their retreat and compelled the fugitives to yield themselves prisoners of war.
10128{_}1169{_}The only fight of any moment had taken place within the camp.
10128{_}1170{_}There, for a few minutes, the Mexicans had fought desperately; two of our regimental colors had been shot down, but finally Anglo-Saxon bone and sinew had triumphed.
10128{_}1171{_}To the exquisite delight of the assailants, the first prize of victory was the guns O'Brien had abandoned at Buena Vista, which were regained by his own regiment.
10128{_}1172{_}Twenty other guns and more than a thousand prisoners, including eighty-eight officers and four generals, were likewise captured, and about fifteen hundred Mexicans killed and wounded.
10128{_}1173{_}The American loss in killed, wounded, and missing was about one hundred men.
10128{_}1174{_}Barely taking time to breathe his troops, Smith followed in pursuit toward the city.
10128{_}1175{_}By ten o'clock in the morning he reached San Angel, which Santa Anna evacuated as he approached.
10128{_}1176{_}The General-in-Chief and the generals of division had by this time relieved Smith of his command.
10128{_}1177{_}Scott rode to the front, and in a few brief words told the men there was more work to be done that day.
10128{_}1178{_}A loud cheer from the ranks was the reply.
10128{_}1179{_}The whole force then advanced to Coyacan, within a mile of Churubusco, and prepared to assault the place.
10128{_}1180{_}Santa Anna considered it the key to the city, and awaited the attack in perfect confidence with thirty thousand men.
10128{_}1181{_}The defences were simple.
10128{_}1182{_}On the west, in the direction of Coyacan, stood the large stone convent of San Pablo, which, as well as the wall and breastworks in front, was filled with infantry, and which contained seven heavy guns.
10128{_}1183{_}A breastwork connected San Pablo with the _tete de pont_ over the Churubusco River, four hundred yards distant.
10128{_}1184{_}This was the easternmost point of defence, and formed part of the San Antonio causeway leading to the city.
10128{_}1185{_}It was a work constructed with the greatest skill--bastions, curtain, and wet ditch, everything was complete and perfect--four guns were mounted in embrasure and barbette, and as many men as the place would hold were stationed there.
10128{_}1186{_}The reserves occupied the causeway behind Churubusco.
10128{_}1187{_}Independently of his defences, Santa Anna's numbers--nearly five to one--should have insured the repulse of the assailants.
10128{_}1188{_}By eleven--hardly seven hours having elapsed since the Contreras camp had been stormed, five miles away--Twiggs and Pillow were in motion toward the San Antonio causeway.
10128{_}1189{_}Nothing had been heard of Worth, who had been directed to move along the east side of the Pedregal on San Antonio, but it was taken for granted he had carried the point, and Scott wished to cut off the retreat of the garrison.
10128{_}1190{_}Twiggs was advancing cautiously toward the convent when a heavy firing was heard in advance.
10128{_}1191{_}Supposing that a reconnoitring party had been attacked, he hastily sent forward the First Artillery, under Dimmick, through a field of tall corn, to support them.
10128{_}1192{_}No sooner had they separated from the main body than a terrific discharge of grape, canister, and musketry assailed them from the convent.
10128{_}1193{_}In the teeth of the storm they advanced to within one hundred yards of that building, and a light battery under Taylor was brought up on their right, and opened on the convent.
10128{_}1194{_}More than an hour the gunners stood firm to their pieces under afire as terrible as troops ever endured; one-third of the command had fallen before they were withdrawn.
10128{_}1195{_}Colonel Riley meanwhile, with the stormers of Contreras, had been despatched to assail San Pablo on the west, and, like Dimmick, was met by a murderous rain of shot.
10128{_}1196{_}Whole heads of companies were mowed down at once.
10128{_}1197{_}Thus Captain Smith fell, twice wounded, with every man beside him; and a single discharge from the Mexican guns swept down Lieutenant Easley and the division he led.
10128{_}1198{_}It was the second time that day the gallant Second had served as targets for the Mexicans, but not a man fell back.
10128{_}1199{_}General Smith ordered up the Third in support, and these, protecting themselves as best they could behind a few huts, kept up a steady fire on the convent.
10128{_}1200{_}Sallies from the works were continually made, and as continually repelled, but not a step could the assailants make in advance.
10128{_}1201{_}By this time the battle was raging at three different points.
10128{_}1202{_}Worth had marched on San Antonio that morning, found it evacuated, and given chase to the Mexicans with the Fifth and Sixth Infantry.
10128{_}1203{_}The causeway leading from San Antonio to the _tete de pont_ of Churubusco was thronged with flying horse and foot; our troops dashed headlong after them, never halting till the advance corps--the Sixth--were within short range of the Mexican batteries.
10128{_}1204{_}A tremendous volley from the _tete de pont_ in front, and the convent on the flank, then forced them to await the arrival of the rest of the division.
10128{_}1205{_}This was the fire which Twiggs heard when he sent Dimmick against the convent.
10128{_}1206{_}Worth came up almost immediately; and directing the Sixth to advance as best they could along the causeway in the teeth of the _tete de pont_, despatched Garland's and Clarke's brigades through the fields on the right to attack it in flank.
10128{_}1207{_}Every gun was instantly directed against the assailants; and though the day was bright and clear, the clouds of smoke actually darkened the air.
10128{_}1208{_}Hoffman, waving his sword, cheered on the Sixth; but the shot tore and ripped up their ranks to such a degree that in a few minutes they had lost ninety-seven men.
10128{_}1209{_}The brigades on the right suffered as severely.
10128{_}1210{_}One hundred men fell within the space of an acre.
10128{_}1211{_}Still they pressed on, till the Eighth (of Clarke's brigade) reached the ditch.
10128{_}1212{_}In they plunged, Lieutenant Longstreet bearing the colors in advance; he scrambled out on the other side, dashed at the walls without ladders or scaling implements, and bayoneted the defenders as they took aim.
10128{_}1213{_}At last, officers and men mixed pell-mell, some through the embrasures, some over the walls, rushed or leaped in and drove the garrison helter-skelter upon their reserves.
10128{_}1214{_}The _tete de pont_ gained, its guns were turned on the convent, whence the Mexicans were still slaughtering our gallant Second and Third.
10128{_}1215{_}Duncan's battery, too, hitherto in reserve, was brought up and opened with such rapidity that a bystander estimated the intervals between the reports at three seconds!
10128{_}1216{_}Stunned by this novel attack, the garrison of San Pablo slackened fire.
10128{_}1217{_}In an instant the Third, followed by Dimmick's artillery, dashed forward with the bayonet to storm the nearest bastion.
10128{_}1218{_}With a run they carried it, the artillery bursting over the curtain; but at that moment a dozen white flags waved in their faces.
10128{_}1219{_}The whole fortified position of Churubusco was taken.
10128{_}1220{_}Meantime, however, a conflict as deadly as either of these was raging behind the Mexican fortifications.
10128{_}1221{_}Soon after the battle commenced, Scott sent Pierce's and Shields's brigades by the left, through the fields, to attack the enemy in the rear.
10128{_}1222{_}On the causeway, opposed to them, were planted Santa Anna's reserves--four thousand foot and three thousand horse--in a measure protected by a dense growth of maguey.
10128{_}1223{_}Shields advanced intrepidly with his force of sixteen hundred.
10128{_}1224{_}The ground was marshy, and for a long distance--having vainly endeavored to outflank the enemy--his advance was exposed to their whole fire.
10128{_}1225{_}Morgan, of the Fifteenth, fell wounded.
10128{_}1226{_}The New York regiment suffered fearfully, and their leader, Colonel Burnett, was disabled.
10128{_}1227{_}The Palmettos of South Carolina, and the Ninth under Ransom, were as severely cut up; and after a while all sought shelter in and about a large barn near the causeway.
10128{_}1228{_}Shields, in an agony at the failure of his movement, cried imploringly for volunteers to follow him.
10128{_}1229{_}The appeal was instantly answered by Colonel Butler, of the Palmettos: "Every South Carolinian will follow you to the death!"
10128{_}1230{_}The cry was contagious, and most of the New Yorkers took it up.
10128{_}1231{_}Forming at angles to the causeway, Shields led these brave men, under an incessant hail of shot, against the village of Portales, where the Mexican reserves were posted.
10128{_}1232{_}Not a trigger was pulled till they stood at a hundred fifty yards from the enemy.
10128{_}1233{_}Then the little band poured in their volley, fatally answered by the Mexican host.
10128{_}1234{_}Butler, already wounded, was shot through the head and died instantly.
10128{_}1235{_}Calling to the Palmettos to avenge his death, Shields gives the word to charge.
10128{_}1236{_}They charge--not four hundred in all--over the plain and down upon four thousand Mexicans securely posted under cover.
10128{_}1237{_}At every step their ranks are thinned.
10128{_}1238{_}Dickenson, who succeeded Butler in command of the Palmettos, seizes the colors as the bearer falls dead; the next moment he is down himself, mortally wounded, and Major Gladden snatches them from his hand.
10128{_}1239{_}Adams, Moragne, and nearly half the gallant band are prostrate.
10128{_}1240{_}A very few minutes more and there will be no one left to bear the glorious flag.
10128{_}1241{_}But at this very moment a deafening roar is heard in the direction of the _tete de pont_.
10128{_}1242{_}Round shot and grape, rifle-balls and canister, come crashing down the causeway into the Mexican ranks from their own battery.
10128{_}1243{_}Worth is there, the gallant fellow, just in time.
10128{_}1244{_}Down the road and over the ditch, through the field and hedge and swamp, in tumult and panic the Mexicans are flying from the bayonets of the Sixth and Garland's brigade.
10128{_}1245{_}A shout, louder than the cannon's peal; Worth is on their heels with his men.
10128{_}1246{_}Before Shields reaches the causeway he is by his side driving the Mexican horse into their infantry, and Ayres is galloping up with a captured Mexican gun.
10128{_}1247{_}Captain Kearny, with a few dragoons, dashes past, rides straight into the flying host, scatters them right and left, sabres all he can reach, and halts before the gate of Mexico.
10128{_}1248{_}Not till then does he perceive that he is alone with his little party, nearly all of whom are wounded; but, despite the hundreds of _escopetas_ that are levelled at him, he gallops back in safety to headquarters.
10128{_}1249{_}The sun, which rose that morning on a proud army and a defiant metropolis, set at even on a shattered, haggard band, and a city full of woe-stricken wretches who did nothing all night but quake with terror, and cry, at every noise, "_Aqui viene los Yanquies_!"
10128{_}1250{_}("Here come the Yankees!")
10128{_}1251{_}All along the causeway, and in the fields and swamps on either side, heaps of dead men and cattle intermingled with broken ammunition-carts, marked where the American shot had told.
10128{_}1252{_}A gory track leading to the _tete de pont_, groups of dead in the fields on the west of Churubusco, over whose pale faces some stalks of tattered corn still waved; red blotches in the marsh next the causeway, where the rich blood of Carolina and New York soaked the earth, showed where the fire of the heavy Mexican guns and the countless _escopetas_ of the infantry had been most murderous.
10128{_}1253{_}Scott had lost, in that day's work, more than a thousand men in killed and wounded, seventy-nine of whom were officers.
10128{_}1254{_}The Mexican loss, according to Santa Anna, was one-third of his army, equal probably to ten thousand men, one-fourth of whom were prisoners, the rest killed and wounded.
10128{_}1255{_}As the sun went down the troops were recalled to headquarters; but all night long the battlefield swarmed with straggling parties seeking some lost comrade in the cold and rain, and surgeons hurrying from place to place and offering succor to the wounded.
10128{_}1256{_}It would have been easy for Scott to march on the city that night, or next morning, and seize it before the Mexicans recovered from the shock of their defeat.
10128{_}1257{_}Anxious to shorten the war, and assured that Santa Anna was desirous of negotiating; warned, moreover, by neutrals and others, that the hostile occupation of the capital would destroy the last chance of peaceable accommodation and rouse the Mexican spirit to resistance all over the country, the American general consented, too generously perhaps, to offer an armistice to his vanquished foe.
10128{_}1258{_}It was eagerly accepted, and negotiations were commenced which lasted over a fortnight.
10128{_}1259{_}In the mean time General Scott had the satisfaction of hanging several of the Irishmen who had deserted to the Mexicans, and, serving as the battalion of San Patricio, had shot down so many of their old comrades at Buena Vista and Churubusco.
10128{_}1260{_}This act of justice was approved by the army and the nation.
10128{_}1261{_}Early in September the treachery of the Mexicans became apparent.
10128{_}1262{_}No progress had been made in the negotiations; and, in defiance of the armistice, an American wagon, proceeding to the city for provisions, had been attacked by the mob and one man killed and others wounded.
10128{_}1263{_}Scott wrote to Santa Anna, demanding an apology, and threatening to terminate the armistice on the 7th if it were not tendered.
10128{_}1264{_}The reply was insulting in the extreme; Santa Anna had repaired his losses and was ready for another fight.
10128{_}1265{_}On the evening of September 7th Worth and his officers were gathered in his quarters at Tacubaya.
10128{_}1266{_}On a table lay a hastily sketched map showing the position of the fortified works at Molino del Rey, with the Casa Mata on one side and the castle of Chapultepec on the other.
10128{_}1267{_}The Molino was occupied by the enemy; there was reason to believe it contained a foundry in full operation, and Worth had been directed to storm it next morning.
10128{_}1268{_}Over that table bent Garland and Clarke, eager to repeat the glorious deeds of August 20th at the _tete de pont_ of Churubusco; Duncan and Smith, already veterans; Wright, the leader of the forlorn hope, joyfully thinking of the morrow; famous Martin Scott, and dauntless Graham, little dreaming that a few hours would see their livid corpses stretched upon the plain; fierce old M'Intosh, covered with scars; Worth himself, his manly brow clouded, and his cheek paled by sickness and anxiety.
10128{_}1269{_}Each officer had his place assigned to him in the conflict; and they parted to seek a few hours' rest.
10128{_}1270{_}At half-past two on the morning of the 8th the division was astir.
10128{_}1271{_}'Twas a bright starlight night whose silence was unbroken as the troops moved thoughtfully toward the battlefield.
10128{_}1272{_}In front, on the right, about a mile from the encampment, the hewn-stone walls of the Molino del Rey--a range of buildings five hundred yards long, and well adapted for defence--were distinctly visible, with drowsy lights twinkling through the windows.
10128{_}1273{_}A little farther off, on the left, stood the black pile of the Casa Mata, the arsenal, crenelled for musketry, and surrounded by a quadrangular field work.
10128{_}1274{_}Beyond the Casa Mata lay a ravine, and from this a ditch and hedge ran, passing in front of both works, to the Tacubaya road.
10128{_}1275{_}Far on the right the grim old castle of Chapultepec loomed up darkly against the sky.
10128{_}1276{_}Sleep wrapped the whole Mexican line, and but few words were spoken in the American ranks as the troops took up their respective positions: Garland, with Dunn's battery and Huger's 24-pounders, on the right, against the Molino; Wright, at the head of the stormers, and followed by the light division under Captain Kirby Smith, in the centre; M'Intosh, with Duncan's battery, on the left, near the ravine looking toward the Casa Mata; and Cadwallader, with his brigade, in reserve.
10128{_}1277{_}Night still overhung the east when the Mexicans were roused from their slumbers by the roar of Huger's 24-pounders, and the crashing of the balls through the roof and walls of the Molino.
10128{_}1278{_}A shout arose within their lines, spreading from the ravine to the castle; lights flashed in every direction, bugles sounded, the clank of arms rang from right to left, and every man girded himself for the fray.
10128{_}1279{_}With the first ray of daylight Major Wright advanced with the forlorn hope down the slope.
10128{_}1280{_}A few seconds elapsed; then a sheet of flame burst from the batteries, and round shot, canister, and grape hurtled through the air.
10128{_}1281{_}"Charge!"
10128{_}1282{_}shouted the leader, and down they went, with double-quick step, over the ditch and hedge, and into the line, sweeping everything before them.
10128{_}1283{_}The Mexicans fell from their guns, but soon, seeing the smallness of the force opposed to them and reassured by the galling fire poured from the _azoteas_ and Molino on the stormers, they rallied, charged furiously, and drove our men back into the plain.
10128{_}1284{_}Here eleven out of the fourteen officers of Wright's party, and the bulk of his men, fell killed or wounded.
10128{_}1285{_}All of the latter who could not fly were bayoneted where they lay by the Mexicans.
10128{_}1286{_}Captain Walker, of the Sixth, badly shot, was left for dead; he saw the enemy murdering every man who showed signs of life, but the agony of thirst was so insupportable that he could not resist raising his canteen to his lips.
10128{_}1287{_}A dozen balls instantly tore up the ground around him; several Mexicans rushed at him with the bayonet, but at that moment the light division, under Kirby Smith, came charging over the ditch into the Mexican line and diverted their attention.
10128{_}1288{_}Garland meanwhile moved down rapidly on the right with Dunn's guns, which were drawn by hand, all the horses having been wounded and become unmanageable.
10128{_}1289{_}These soon opened an enfilading fire on the Mexican battery; and some of the gunners flying, the light division charged, under a hot fire, and carried the guns for the second time.
10128{_}1290{_}Their gallant leader was shot dead in the charge.
10128{_}1291{_}But the enemy could afford to lose the battery.
10128{_}1292{_}From the tops of the _azoteas_, from the Casa Mata and the Molino, a deadly shower of balls was rained crosswise upon the assailants.
10128{_}1293{_}Part of the reserve was brought up; and Dunn's guns and the Mexican battery were served upon the buildings without much effect at first.
10128{_}1294{_}Lieutenant-Colonel Graham led a party of the Eleventh against the latter; when within pistol-shot a terrific volley assailed him, wounding him in ten places.
10128{_}1295{_}The gallant soldier quietly dismounted, pointed with his sword to the building, cried "Charge!"
10128{_}1296{_}and sank dead on the field.
10128{_}1297{_}As fiercely raged the battle at the other wing where Duncan and M'Intosh had driven in the enemy's right toward the Casa Mata.
10128{_}1298{_}M'Intosh started to storm that fort, and, in the teeth of a tremendous hail of musketry, advanced to the ditch, only twenty-five yards from the work.
10128{_}1299{_}There a ball knocked him down; it was his luck to be shot or bayoneted in every battle.
10128{_}1300{_}Martin Scott took the command, but as he ordered the men forward he rolled lifeless into the ditch.
10128{_}1301{_}Major Waite, the next in rank, had hardly seen him fall before he too was disabled.
10128{_}1302{_}By whole companies the men were mowed down by the Mexican shot; but they stood their ground.
10128{_}1303{_}At length some one gave the word to fall back, and the remnants of the brigade obeyed.
10128{_}1304{_}Many wounded were left on the ground; among others Lieutenant Burnell, shot in the leg, whom the Mexicans murdered when his comrades abandoned him.
10128{_}1305{_}After the battle his body was found, and beside it his dog, moaning piteously and licking his dead master's face.
10128{_}1306{_}At the head of four thousand cavalry, Alvarez now menaced our left.
10128{_}1307{_}Duncan watched them come, driving a cloud of dust before them, till they were within close range; then opening with his wonderful rapidity, he shattered whole platoons at a discharge.
10128{_}1308{_}Worth sent him word to be sure to keep the lancers in check.
10128{_}1309{_}"Tell General Worth," was his reply, "to make himself perfectly easy; I can whip twenty thousand of them."
10128{_}1310{_}So far as Alvarez was concerned, he kept his word.
10128{_}1311{_}On the American right the fight had reached a crisis.
10128{_}1312{_}Mixed confusedly together, men of all arms furiously attacked the Molino, firing into every aperture, climbing to the roof, and striving to batter in the doors and gates with their muskets.
10128{_}1313{_}The garrison never slackened their terrible fire for an instant.
10128{_}1314{_}At length Major Buchanan, of the Fourth, succeeded in bursting open the southern gate; and almost at the same moment Anderson and Ayres, of the artillery, forced their way into the buildings at the northwestern angle.
10128{_}1315{_}Ayres leaped down alone into a crowd of Mexicans--he had done the same at Monterey--and fell covered with wounds.
10128{_}1316{_}Our men rushed in on both sides, stabbing, firing, and felling the Mexicans with their muskets.
10128{_}1317{_}From room to room and house to house a hand-to-hand encounter was kept up.
10128{_}1318{_}Here a stalwart Mexican hurled down man after man as they advanced; there Buchanan and the Fourth levelled all before them.
10128{_}1319{_}But the Mexicans never withstood the cold steel.
10128{_}1320{_}One by one the defenders escaped by the rear toward Chapultepec, and those who remained hung out a white flag.
10128{_}1321{_}Under Duncan's fire the Casa Mata had been evacuated, and the enemy was everywhere in full retreat.
10128{_}1322{_}Twice he rallied and charged the Molino; but each time the artillery drove him back toward Chapultepec, and parties of the light infantry pursued him down the road.
10128{_}1323{_}Before ten in the morning the whole field was won; and, having blown up the Casa Mata, Worth, by Scott's order, fell back to Tacubaya.
10128{_}1324{_}With gloomy face and averted eye the gallant soldier received the thanks of his chief for the exploits of the morning.
10128{_}1325{_}His heart was with the brave men he had lost--nearly eight hundred out of less than thirty-five hundred and among them fifty-eight officers, many of whom were his dearest friends.
10128{_}1326{_}All had fallen in advance of their men, with sword in hand and noble words on their lips.
10128{_}1327{_}'Twas a poor price for these to have stormed Molino del Rey, and cut down nearly a fifth of Santa Anna's fourteen thousand men.
10128{_}1328{_}Sadly the General returned to his quarters.
10128{_}1329{_}The end was now close at hand.
10128{_}1330{_}Reconnoissances were carefully made, and, the enemy's strength being gathered on the southern front of the city, General Scott determined to assail Chapultepec on the west.
10128{_}1331{_}By the morning of the 12th the batteries were completed, and opened a brisk fire on the castle, without, however, doing any more serious damage than annoying the garrison and killing a few men.
10128{_}1332{_}The fire was kept up all day; and at night preparations were made for the assault, which was ordered to be made next morning.
10128{_}1333{_}At daybreak on the 13th the cannonade began again, as well from the batteries planted against Chapultepec as from Steptoe's guns, which were served against the southern defences of the city in order to divert the attention of the enemy.
10128{_}1334{_}At 8 A.M. the firing from the former ceased, and the attack commenced.
10128{_}1335{_}Quitman advanced along the Tacubaya road, Pillow from the Molino del Rey, which he had occupied on the evening before.
10128{_}1336{_}Between the Molino and the castle lay first an open space, then a grove thickly planted with trees; in the latter, Mexican sharpshooters had been posted, protected by an intrenchment on the border of the grove.
10128{_}1337{_}Pillow sent Lieutenant-Colonel Johnston with a party of _voltigeurs_ to turn this work by a flank movement; it was handsomely accomplished; and just as the _voltigeurs_ broke through the redan, Pillow, with the main body, charged it in front and drove back the Mexicans.
10128{_}1338{_}The grove gained, Pillow pressed forward to the front of the rock; for the Mexican shot from the castle batteries, crashing through the trees, seemed even more terrible than it really was, and the troops were becoming restless.
10128{_}1339{_}The Mexicans had retreated to a redoubt half way up the hill; the _voltigeurs_ sprang up from rock to rock, firing as they advanced, and followed by Hooker, Chase, and others, with parties of infantry.
10128{_}1340{_}In a very few minutes the redoubt was gained, the garrison driven up the hill, and the _voltigeurs_, Ninth, and Fifteenth were in hot pursuit after them.
10128{_}1341{_}The firing from the castle was very severe.
10128{_}1342{_}Colonel Ransom, of the Ninth, was killed, and Pillow himself was wounded.
10128{_}1343{_}Still the troops pressed on till the crest of the hill was gained.
10128{_}1344{_}There some moments were lost owing to the delay in the arrival of scaling-ladders, during which two of Quitman's regiments and Clarke's brigade reenforced the storming party.
10128{_}1345{_}When the ladders came, numbers of men rushed forward with them, leaped into the ditch, and planted them for the assault.
10128{_}1346{_}Lieutenant Selden was the first man to mount.
10128{_}1347{_}But the Mexicans collected all their energies for this last moment.
10128{_}1348{_}A tremendous fire dashed the foremost of the stormers into the ditch, killing Lieutenants Rogers and Smith and clearing the ladders.
10128{_}1349{_}Fresh men instantly manned them, and, after a brief struggle, Captain Howard, of the _voltigeurs_, gained a foothold on the parapet.
10128{_}1350{_}M'Kenzie, of the forlorn hope, followed; and a crowd of _voltigeurs_ and infantry, shouting and cheering, pressed after him, and swept down upon the garrison with the bayonet.
10128{_}1351{_}Almost at the same moment, Johnston, of the _voltigeurs_, who had led a small party round to the gate of the castle, broke it open and effected an entrance in spite of a fierce fire from the southern walls.
10128{_}1352{_}The two parties uniting, a deadly conflict ensued within the building.
10128{_}1353{_}Maddened by the recollection of the murder of their wounded comrades at Molino del Rey, the stormers at first showed no quarter.
10128{_}1354{_}On every side the Mexicans were stabbed or shot down without mercy.
10128{_}1355{_}Many flung themselves over the parapet and down the hillside and were dashed in pieces against the rocks.
10128{_}1356{_}More fought like fiends, expending their breath in a malediction, and expiring in the act of aiming a treacherous blow as they lay on the ground.
10128{_}1357{_}Streams of blood flowed through the doors of the college, and every room and passage was the theatre of some deadly struggle.
10128{_}1358{_}At length the officers succeeded in putting an end to the carnage; and the remaining Mexicans having surrendered, the Stars and Stripes were hoisted over the castle of Chapultepec by Major Seymour.
10128{_}1359{_}Meanwhile Quitman had stormed the batteries on the causeway to the east of the castle, after a desperate struggle in which Major Twiggs, who commanded the stormers, was shot dead at the head of his men.
10128{_}1360{_}The Mexicans fell back toward the city.
10128{_}1361{_}General Scott, coming up at this moment, ordered a simultaneous advance to be made on the city, along the two roads leading from Chapultepec to the gates of San Cosme and Belen, respectively.
10128{_}1362{_}Worth was to command that on San Cosme, Quitman that on Belen.
10128{_}1363{_}Both were prepared for defence by barricades, behind which the enemy were posted in great numbers.
10128{_}1364{_}Fortunately for the assailants an aqueduct, supported by arches of solid masonry, ran along the centre of each causeway.
10128{_}1365{_}By keeping under cover of these arches, and springing rapidly from one to another, Smith's rifles and the South Carolina regiment were enabled to advance close to the first barricade on the Belen road, and pour in a destructive fire on the gunners.
10128{_}1366{_}A flank discharge from Duncan's guns completed the work; the barricade was carried; and without a moment's rest Quitman advanced in the same manner on the _garita_ San Belen, which was held by General Torres with a strong garrison.
10128{_}1367{_}It too was stormed, though under a fearful hail of grape and canister; and the rifles moved forward toward the citadel.
10128{_}1368{_}But at this moment Santa Anna rode furiously down to the point of attack.
10128{_}1369{_}Boiling with rage at the success of the invaders, he smote General Torres in the face, threw a host of infantry into the houses commanding the _garita_ and the road, ordered the batteries in the citadel to open fire, planted fresh guns on the Paseo, and infused such spirit into the Mexicans that Quitman's advance was stopped at once.
10128{_}1370{_}A terrific storm of shot, shell, and grape assailed the _garita_, where Captain Dunn had planted an 8-pounder.
10128{_}1371{_}Twice the gunners were shot down, and fresh men sent to take their places.
10128{_}1372{_}Then Dunn himself fell, and immediately afterward Lieutenant Benjamin and his first sergeant met the same fate.
10128{_}1373{_}The riflemen in the arches repelled sallies; but Quitman's position was precarious, till night terminated the conflict.
10128{_}1374{_}Worth meanwhile had advanced in like manner along the San Cosme causeway, driving the Mexicans from barricade to barricade, till within two hundred fifty yards of the _garita_ of San Cosme.
10128{_}1375{_}There he encountered as severe a fire as that which stopped Quitman.
10128{_}1376{_}But Scott had ordered him to take the _garita_, and take it he would.
10128{_}1377{_}Throwing Garland's brigade out to the right and Clarke's to the left, he ordered them to break into the houses, burst through the walls, and bore their way to the flanks of the _garita_.
10128{_}1378{_}The plan had succeeded perfectly at Monterey, nor did it fail here.
10128{_}1379{_}Slowly but surely the sappers passed from house to house, until at sunset they reached the point desired.
10128{_}1380{_}Then Worth ordered the attack.
10128{_}1381{_}Lieutenant Hunt brought up a light gun at a gallop, and fired it through the embrasure of the enemy's battery, almost muzzle to muzzle; the infantry at the same moment opened a most deadly and unexpected fire from the roofs of the houses, and M'Kenzie, at the head of the stormers, dashed at the battery and carried it almost without loss.
10128{_}1382{_}The Mexicans fled precipitately into the city.
10128{_}1383{_}At one that night two parties left the citadel and issued forth from the city.
10128{_}1384{_}One was the remnant of the Mexican army, which slunk silently and noiselessly through the northern gate, and fled to Guadalupe-Hidalgo; the other was a body of officers who came under a white flag, to propose terms of capitulation.
10128{_}1385{_}The sun shone brightly on the morning of September 14th.
10128{_}1386{_}Scores of neutral flags float from the windows on the Calle de Plateros, and in their shade beautiful women gaze curiously on the scene beneath.
10128{_}1387{_}Gayly dressed groups throng the balconies, and at the street-corners dark-faced men scowl, mutter deep curses, and clutch their knives.
10128{_}1388{_}The street resounds with the heavy tramp of infantry, the rattle of gun-carriages, and the clatter of horses' hoofs.
10128{_}1389{_}"_Los Yanquies_!"
10128{_}1390{_}is the cry, and every neck is stretched to obtain a glimpse of the six thousand bemired and begrimed soldiers who are marching proudly to the Grand Plaza.
10128{_}1391{_}On him especially is every eye intently fixed, whose martial form is half concealed by a splendid staff and a squadron of dragoons, as he rides, with flashing eye and beating heart, to the National Palace of Mexico.
10128{_}1392{_}But six months before, Winfield Scott had landed on the Mexican coast; since then he had stormed the two strongest places in the country, won four battles in the field against armies double, treble, and quadruple his own, and marched without reverse from Vera Cruz to the City of Mexico; losing fewer men, making fewer mistakes, and creating less devastation, in proportion to his victories, than any invading general of former times.
10128{_}1393{_}Well might the Mexicans gaze upon his face!
10128{_}1394{_}(1847) FAMINE IN IRELAND, Sir Charles Gavan Duffy   From the fact that its immediate cause was the almost complete failure of the potato crop, due to the rot, the great Irish famine is known as the "potato famine."
10128{_}1395{_}The crop that suffered so was that of 1845, and the famine began in the following year and reached its climax in 1847.
10128{_}1396{_}It is estimated that by this calamity two hundred thousand persons perished.
10128{_}1397{_}Many compensating features in connection with this appalling distress have been pointed out.
10128{_}1398{_}Some writers friendly toward Ireland have declared that the famine proved one of the greatest blessings to the country; that it hastened free trade, better drainage of the island, and the passage of the Land Improvement Act; that it relieved the overcrowded labor market, led to more scientific farming, and in other ways produced changes that have been of lasting benefit.
10128{_}1399{_}But though all this be true, the misfortune itself gave to modern history one of its most harrowing chapters.
10128{_}1400{_}The population of Ireland in 1845 is supposed to have been nearly nine millions.
10128{_}1401{_}The manufactures were small, and the people depended on the potato crop, and had no other resource in time of scarcity.
10128{_}1402{_}For several years the potato yield had been abundant, the country was comparatively prosperous, and the temperance movement led by Father Mathew promised a happier future.
10128{_}1403{_}A great harvest was expected in 1845, but almost at a single stroke this expectation was blasted; for although the crop was large the greater part of it was destroyed in the ground, and the potatoes that were gathered "rotted in pit and storehouse."
10128{_}1404{_}The farmers taxed all their means and energies to secure even a larger crop in 1846, but the blight of that year was even more fatal than the last.
10128{_}1405{_}To pinching want was added discouragement, and the people sat in the shadow of a frightful catastrophe.
10128{_}1406{_}In vain the British Government was called upon to give relief through Parliament, until, in the autumn of 1846, parliamentary authority was obtained to grant baronial loans.
10128{_}1407{_}But these and every local endeavor to mitigate the suffering failed, and the destructive work of the famine continued, the number of victims increasing, to the end of that fatal year.
10128{_}1408{_}The horrors of 1846 were more than equalled by those of the year that followed, and the woful picture presented by Sir Charles Gavan Duffy, the distinguished Irish patriot, statesman, and historian, is but too amply justified by the accepted records of the time.
10128{_}1409{_}The condition of Ireland at the opening of the year 1847 is one of the most painful chapters in the annals of mankind.
10128{_}1410{_}An industrious and hospitable race were in the pangs of a devouring famine.
10128{_}1411{_}Deaths of individuals, of husband and wife, of entire families, were becoming common.
10128{_}1412{_}The potato-blight had spread from the Atlantic to the Caspian; but there was more suffering in one parish of Mayo than in all the rest of Europe.
10128{_}1413{_}From Connaught, where distress was greatest, came batches of inquests with the horrible verdict "died of starvation."
10128{_}1414{_}In some instances the victims were buried "wrapped in a coarse coverlet," a coffin being too costly a luxury.
10128{_}1415{_}The living awaited death with a listlessness that was at once tragic and revolting.
10128{_}1416{_}Women with dead children in their arms were seen begging for a coffin to bury them.
10128{_}1417{_}Beranger has touched a thousand hearts by the picture of _Pauvre Jacques_, who, when the tax-gatherer came in the King's name, was discovered dead on his miserable pallet.
10128{_}1418{_}But at Skibbereen, in the fruitful County Cork whose seaports were thronged with vessels laden with corn, cattle, and butter for England, the rate collector told a more tragic tale.
10128{_}1419{_}Some houses he found deserted; the owners had been carried to their graves.
10128{_}1420{_}In one cabin there was no other occupant than three corpses; in a once prosperous home a woman and her children had lain dead and unburied for a week; in the fields a man was discovered so fearfully mangled by dogs that identification was impossible.
10128{_}1421{_}The relief committee of the Society of Friends described the state of the town in language which it was hard to read with dry eyes.
10128{_}1422{_}The people were dying of the unaccustomed food which mocked their prayer for daily bread, and were carried to the graveyard in a coffin from which the benevolent strangers who had come to their relief had to drop them, like dead dogs, that there might be a covering for the next corpse in its turn.
10128{_}1423{_}"This place is one mass of famine, disease, and death.
10128{_}1424{_}The poor creatures, hitherto trying to exist on one meal a day, are now sinking under fever and bowel complaints, unable to come for their soup, which is not fit for them.
10128{_}1425{_}Rice is what their whole cry is for, but we cannot manage this well, nor can we get the food carried to the houses, from dread of infection.
10128{_}1426{_}I have got a coffin constructed with movable sides, to convey the bodies to the churchyard, in calico bags prepared, in which the remains are wrapped up.
